website_summaries.verdict: A compact manual coffee grinder that you can take with you anywhere for brewing that perfect cup of coffee.
pros: 18 grind settings to give you control over the level of coarseness
Compact cylinder that's perfect for travel
Built-in window to see your progress
cons: Some users have reported the plastic pieces breaking off after several months

website_summaries.verdict: A solid, budget-friendly manual grinder that competes with many higher-end models.
pros: More than 18 settings to control for different types of coffee
Ceramic conical burr lasts up to five times longer than stainless steel blades
cons: Takes a while to grind beans manually

customer_reviews.title: Turn it up to 11 and reallywatch the window load with mounds o' grounds
customer_reviews.text: Throw that handle away and get out to the toolshed. The Miluakee 8 amp Magnum serves me well in the mornin'. Who wants to quietly grind away at the pile of beans their little hand grinder for half an hour anyways? Turn it up to 11 and really watch the window load with mounds o' grounds. It's kind if like internet were to have suddenly jumped from dial-up to fiber. Is it the intended use? No. But is OSHA going to come issue a notice or something? I'm a man and I do what I please, structural integrity be damned. Its not like the thing cost $100.
customer_reviews.author: Matt

customer_reviews.title: Terrible Quality
customer_reviews.text: First thing out of the box, I loosen the burr to test turn it and the burr is offset, narrow on one end wide on the other. I take it off to inspect it for any debris that could cause it, and the ceramic burr itself is pitted and deformed. The plastic insert holding the burr to the central rod is loose, letting the burr wobble and not get a consistent grind.When I set it to a "fine" size, the burr will press against the outer wall, making it hard to turn. All in all garbage quality product. Don't waste your time ordering this to just have to return it.
customer_reviews.author: Dan Miner

customer_reviews.title: Waste of money!
customer_reviews.text: This grinder lasted less than 6 months of daily use. I was hoping that it would be a good purchase since I don't want a grinder that requires electricity. Apparently the search is still on. This grinder has cheap plastic parts inside that snapped in half. I do not recommend for anyone looking for a good grinder....
customer_reviews.author: The German

customer_reviews.title: Would not purchase again
customer_reviews.text: The design seems flawed, in that the cone isn't held in perfect concentricy with the cup, therefore creating a grind that's comprised of varying ground sizes. Every time. Would not buy it again, even after having a replacement sent to me. The folks at the company were great to deal with, but I have to wonder if they don't realize they have a dog on their hands.
customer_reviews.author: JB

customer_reviews.title: does what it needs to
customer_reviews.text: Pretty solid, however, settings seemed to be skewed to the coarse vs. fine side in regard to the setting of the grind. Also the handle is clearly made of a different material than the stainless steel body and you have to be careful not to get it wet because mine rusted after one day of air drying by the sink - UPDATE THE INTERNAL MECHANISM BROKE DOWN IN ABOUT 2 WEEKS THIS PRODUCT IS CHEAP AND DOES NOT HOLD UP
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Very inconsistent grinds!
customer_reviews.text: I don’t mind taking my time to grind the coffee, however this grinder produced very inconsistent results - the bottom of the grounds have the large chunks, and the finely ground coffee sits at the top. See picture for the “fine” grind setting. Thought I would be getting a better product given the great reviews...
customer_reviews.author: Sheng

customer_reviews.title: Trash.
customer_reviews.text: I had very high expectations for this product due to the price and reviews. The fit of the pieces is excessively tight. I have to strain myself to get this thing apart and back together. Started turning the handle clockwise as recommended and the screw holding the crank on just fell out. It's not even reverse threaded, so the crank just falls apart with normal use. Returning this.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Loved it until it broke!
customer_reviews.text: great little grinder but after 6 months the plastic piece inside the ceramic part broke. I hope I can buy this replacement part.
customer_reviews.author: shiborigirl

customer_reviews.title: Is this a joke?
customer_reviews.text: I was convinced by the stellar reviews that this would be a decent grinder for the price, boy was I wrong. The first one I got was off center and the ceramic burr would grind on itself, so it was useless. They sent a prompt replacement that ended up being even more off than the first one. Steer clear of this super cheap and flimsy grinder. Even with the burr problem, the metal feels paper thin and there are a lot of plastic components that can and probably will eventually break. Very poor quality.
customer_reviews.author: Layla

customer_reviews.title: Junk, don't buy
customer_reviews.text: I would not recommend this item. The grind is very inconsistent, especially at the medium - course settings. When grinding medium-course for Chemex, this produces a ton of fines. These fines over extract and add bitterness to every cup you brew. Today, half the grinds were medium course and the other half were fine! It clogged the filter and ruined the brew! If you're grinding more fine for Aeropress then this thing works okay, but truly you'd be better off saving your money, increasing your budget, and buying a much nicer grinder.
customer_reviews.author: davis

customer_reviews.title: Uneven grind
customer_reviews.text: The burr is able to pivot, creating a side that produces larger grind than the other. It also unscrews in the same direction as the crank. This results in the adjustable grind size to become larger as you rotate. This results in a final product that has a mixture of the fine grind one may be hoping for and large chunks. If you are getting this to make your ground coffee more evenly sized (something the motorized grinder has a hard time achieving) you may want to keep looking.
customer_reviews.author: Moana Sato

customer_reviews.title: The coffee grinder arrived as promised. I've been using ...
customer_reviews.text: I've used the JavaPresse coffee grinder for a few weeks now. I like the feel of it when grinding coffee. I use the AeroPress and like a more coarse grind so the adjustments make it great for that. I've found that filling the top portion full of coffee beans is the perfect amount to brew a single cup of coffee. Should have purchased this grinder a long time ago.
customer_reviews.author: Mike

customer_reviews.title: Quality is lacking.  Lasted until 2 days after return window closed.
customer_reviews.text: I wanted to like this hand coffee grinder. But, the quality is lacking. I ordered August 26, received August 28. Tonight (September 28) the item stopped working. The ceramic burr became stuck and no longer grinds. I realize the price is low, but 1 month is unacceptable. I'll be contacting the manufacturer, and depending on the response I may update this review to reflect the customer service experience.
customer_reviews.author: Floyd

customer_reviews.title: Handle Rusted & water retained in between the plastic and metal!
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this product based on the good reviews, but ended up being so disappointed!!! First, the plastic part inside the mill is not well sealed, so you can see in my first picture that there is water remained in between the plastic and the metal, after each rinse! Second, the handle got rusted after ONE rinse before I used it (not even with any detergent, I just rinse it with water and let it air dry over night). Thirdly, the grinding is not as smooth as it seems to be.
customer_reviews.author: AQ

customer_reviews.title: Not built to last
customer_reviews.text: This grinder is nice, but it isn't constructed to last. The handle is connected to a metal shaft that goes down to the ceramic burr. The ceramic burr has a hole in the center that the metal shaft connects to. It is secured to the shaft with a piece of plastic. The center plastic on mine broke and the shafts just spins, not turning the burr at all. However, when it did work It worked great. I was able to enjoy many of cups of fresh ground coffee because of it. I wouldn't recommend using it full time at home, but for a small simple grinder to take camping it would be fine.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Worst exercise program ever conceived
customer_reviews.text: Fill with beans, set to medium grind, turn handle 100 times, get about a tablespoon of grind, To empty the top hopper would require somewhere around 800 rotations. I value my wrists and elbows too much for this TOTAL lying nonsense. Apparently every other 'reviewer' is a paid for hack.
customer_reviews.author: lonewolfmtn

customer_reviews.title: Not worth it...buy a higher quality grinder.
customer_reviews.text: Well, i used it every day for two weeks at work. And today, I started getting an inconsistent grind (horribly inconsistent). Took it apart to find the burrs damaged with chipped teeth. I was going for a medium grind for pour over coffee. I’m thinking, the slight wiggle in the burrs while grinding caused it. Not happy, I guess that’s what I get when I go the cheapest rout. In comparison to my Knock aergrind, the JavaPresse is a toy in a world of true tools.
customer_reviews.author: Rodney

customer_reviews.title: Very slow. My kettle boils before I can finish ...
customer_reviews.text: Very slow. My kettle boils before I can finish grinding one canister for the French press, using a drill on low speed at home. I bought it for camping, takes about 10 minutes to grind enough coarse ground for a camping kettle. Does the job and is very compact.
customer_reviews.author: Robert Loy

customer_reviews.title: Broke in about 3 months of use.
customer_reviews.text: I bought this product in December 2019 and it broke while using at home in March 2020. When I turn the arm the entire internal housing rotates so no coffee and not only that it’s during the pandemic so I’m in a serious situation here. I NEED COFFEE. I may have to take my hammer and mash it up. Please help!!!!!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistency. Shaft not centered
customer_reviews.text: The shaft is way off the center. I unscrewed more than 10 clicks and still could hear burr rubbing outer ring. I had bought a similar looking one (the same look with different company logo) at half the price of this and had the same issue. I was hoping "the higher the price, the better", but it only disappointed me. I will avoid buying grinders of this particular shape. When precision or accuracy is needed, I've had better luck with products that were made in Japan, Korea ( not North Korea), Taiwan, Germany along with USA.
customer_reviews.author: Paul L

customer_reviews.title: Loved at first..
customer_reviews.text: It was a great at first, but after about a month of daily use (once a day) it started to take longer and longer to grind, then eventually stopped working. The plastic piece inside the grinder morphed and even when I shoved it back into place with pliers it would keep popping out. Super disappointing, at almost $30 I would’ve hoped it lasted more than a month.
customer_reviews.author: Morgan Stewart

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent grinds
customer_reviews.text: Second time I've purchased this style of coffee grinder (different brand but identical product) and they seem to pretty much be the same. This product would work splendidly if the conical but grinder wasn't always offset. This causes grinds to never be consistent. Would not recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Phil

customer_reviews.title: Very poorly constructed for a $45 item.
customer_reviews.text: The item was poorly manufactured and poorly constructed. The outer burr ring was not secured and the plastic housing for it was too long which caused it to be loose within the body. I ended up having to break the plastic housing out, shave about 1/8th of an inch of plastic off the end, glue the burr ring into that, then glue the plastic housing back into the main body. I'm extremely disappointed with the poor design and construction considering I paid $45 for this item. It works great after I fixed it, but for the price, I shouldn't have had to risk breaking it to make it work properly.
customer_reviews.author: Kirk Baldwin

customer_reviews.title: Good for Travel
customer_reviews.text: It's a nice little machine, but, it's getting two stars because you'll be sitting there, grinding, and grinding, and grinding, and grinding, and grinding... Oh the water's done, still grinding, and grinding, and grinding, and grinding. I have an old wood one from my aunt that is essentially the same concept but with a cast iron burr, and it takes a fraction of the time, same handle length etc... Wish I spent the extra money and got a motorized one, now that I'm turning into a coffee nerd.
customer_reviews.author: Eric E.

customer_reviews.title: If you drive this with a screw gun...
customer_reviews.text: ...it makes a workable coffee grinder. I also tried putting the thing in a lathe, and the coffee came out just incredible. Working the handle by hand is not really practical unless you gobble up a bunch of addaralls beforehand, in which case you won't be needing coffee to start with. Ok, I'm kidding, it's a nice little mill. Not very quick, and working the handle might be difficult. I am inclined to recommend excersizing with pornhub before attempting to grind coffee with this mill.
customer_reviews.author: some guy

customer_reviews.title: Uneven grind, Loose base
customer_reviews.text: Two issues... 1) Uneven grind - I am getting an entire spectrum of grind sizes. Without any beans in it, brand new, I could hear the burr scraping one side. I can push it away from the side and it will stop but it should not have that much movement in the first place. 2) Loose base - The base and main body are not very tight. I thought they would screw together but it just pulls apart. The connection is not that tight. Am I really expected to hold both parts at the same time with one hand while grinding with the other?
customer_reviews.author: Torrentula81

customer_reviews.title: Takes too long to grind.
customer_reviews.text: Save your money and buy another grinder. No matter what setting or clicks you set on the grinder it just takes way too long. I tried grinding only one scoop (for one cup) thinking that it would be easier for the grinder but it didn't make any difference. I even ran it with an electric drill for several minutes but it just wouldn't grind well. I'm going to continue using my Krups blade grinder, I run it intermittently by pushing the button 10 times and not continuously. I have medium to coarse ground coffee in just a few seconds. If I want a finer grind, I do more cycles or do them longer.
customer_reviews.author: ARPI2000

customer_reviews.title: Great for every kind of grind
customer_reviews.text: I’m in love with this grinder. It can be used for all types of grind. From French press to Turkish grind. I use this every day to make fresh coffee with my pour over or aero press. Durability of this product is amazing as well. One part that is slightly difficult is taking it apart to clean but don’t let that scare you! Because it’s worth every penny this product is! So why not give it a try! It’s cheap! High quality parts!
customer_reviews.author: Kouki Chrisp

customer_reviews.title: Good for a year
customer_reviews.text: This worked really well for about a year. I used it in average once a day. The last time I used it I heard the sounds of ceramic grinding against ceramic and discovered the plastic that keeps the shaft centered broken into brittle pieces. Strange that an almost all metal construction would use cheap plastic where the most stress is. I don't recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel G

customer_reviews.title: Work your forearms and make perfectly ground coffee - what could be better?
customer_reviews.text: So this is small and light- only 8" tall and about 1.5" diameter. The crank is a good size though and it's a good thing - you are gonna be using it a lot! Take about 3 minutes of grinding to get a couple of tablespoons. I recommend switching up the holding hand to get both arms well worked! But it works great and the coffee has that perfect grind when you are done which is very rewarding.
customer_reviews.author: Sleepless

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the money
customer_reviews.text: It lasted me about 2 days before the grinder became offset, with one side producing larger grinds than the other. After about a week I had a problem where while cranking it would skip. The skipping became more and more common until it wouldn't grind at all. I tried to take the cone off to see what was wrong and it ended up breaking the spring action for the adjustment, making it useless. Don't waste your money.
customer_reviews.author: en davis

customer_reviews.title: Buyer beware
customer_reviews.text: Purchased in January 2020, only made it into August. I contacted the manufacturer, they sent me troubleshooting steps. After cleaning, it only made it worse, they sent me a replacement immediately. If it breaks again, I'm buying a different brand. Huge tip, stick to the same brand of coffee so you don't have to clean it. After I cleaned it is when I started having issues.
customer_reviews.author: Carlos Moreno

customer_reviews.title: Only worked for a couple grinds
customer_reviews.text: It only worked for a couple grinds and then the mechanism developed a wobble and the grind got really uneven. Cannot recommend.
customer_reviews.author: SG

customer_reviews.title: Type of Roast Matters
customer_reviews.text: I'm on my second Javapresse unit, because the first one failed. The weakest link, imo, is not the ceramic burr, but the plastic connector underneath the burr, which breaks; when it fails, the handle turn without turning the burr, like when you strip a nail. PLEASE REPLACE THIS PART WITH SOMETHING STRONGER. I will note that daily use of the Javapresse for light (and maybe medium) roast beans likely caused me Javapresse to fail. You can tell when grinding: a light roasted bean, is much much harder than a dark roasted one. The Javapresse grinds dark roasted beans like butter; but a light roast yielding harder beans, might damage it.
customer_reviews.author: Joe P.

customer_reviews.title: Overpriced piece of junk
customer_reviews.text: This thing is an overpriced piece of junk. Yes, it has a fancy burr grinder, but the rest of it is garbage. The top and bottom don’t stay attached, so you have to hold both together WHILE grinding, which by the way, takes about 50 cranks to get enough grinds for one cup of coffee. The real reason I’m upset with this product is that the black plastic piece that adjusts the size of the grinds fell off when it was on the largest setting and is now gone. I’ve reached out to javapresse, but they don’t offer this replacement part even though this is the only product they make.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Upgraded to an electric grinder after a few uses
customer_reviews.text: I initially bought this since it was about half as expensive as an electric burr mill, but after a few uses I gave it away to a friend and bought an electric grinder. Unless you have a valid reason to buy this instead of an electric grinder (camping maybe?) then the electric grinder is absolutely worth the money. Starting off the day with 5 minutes of cranking is not worth saving $20.
customer_reviews.author: Jonathan

customer_reviews.title: Great Small Grinder
customer_reviews.text: This is a great grinder for making small batches of coffee. It does take a bit to grind enough to make a pot of coffee but it is easy and straightforward. You do need to make sure you hold the two halves together otherwise the bottom can pop off and you'll spill the coffee you ground (I made that mistake). It's also small and compact so it's perfect for storing in your kitchen. If you always grind your coffee, then you will probably want to get a bigger automatic grinder but this is great if you manually grind coffee every once in awhile.
customer_reviews.author: Jasmine Norris-Dixson

customer_reviews.title: I regret not buying electric
customer_reviews.text: This had great reviews so I was super excited to get it for making fresh espresso grounds. In hindsight, I wish I had bought an electric one. It takes me about 7 minutes to grind enough for 2.5 doubleshots of espresso. It does work okay, but that's more time that I want to commit each day for my caffeine kick, especially in the morning when I'm still tired. On the plus side, it's quiet. Cleaning has a lot of parts to disassemble, but I found it easy enough. I paid $25 which seemed a little high at the time, but it's currently listed at $43.99 - YIKES!
customer_reviews.author: Krista

customer_reviews.title: Broke the second time I used it, terrible design, cheap material.
customer_reviews.text: I was already unimpressed with how flimsy the material is, the fact you have to remove the crank to load it, the way the two pieces fit together in such a way that it detaches as you grind unless you hold it in place while you grind. And the second time I used it the entire grinding area started to spin so nothing is ground it just spins. Overall from design to material this whole product is a failure.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Very disappointed. Maybe I got a defect?
customer_reviews.text: After extensive research and investing a lot of money trying to up my coffee game, I’m really disappointed. I specifically chose a manual burr grinder and reading the importance of “consistency” of grounds. I used this grinder dozens of times and the grounds are all over the place in size. Plus it never seems to stay on the setting I select from one day to the next. Monday I’ll have a mix of coarse grounds, and Tuesday it will be so fine it looks like I’m making espresso. I really wanted to like this grinder and I purchased it because of the generally favorable reviews. Maybe mine is defective?
customer_reviews.author: TLJack

customer_reviews.title: Works great. A lot of work
customer_reviews.text: This thing works exactly as advertised. For those of us who like to feel like we really really earned our cup of coffee, this is the coffee grinder for you. It works really well, can get extremely fine down to espresso ground, and is very consistent. But it’s a lot of work. I can’t imagine anyone using this thing for ALL of their coffee Actually, I sort of figured out a little hack. There is a hexagonal bolt that the handle fits onto for grinding. I figured out I can actually clamp that sucker right into my power drill. Problem solved.
customer_reviews.author: Fugio

customer_reviews.title: Works well for travel
customer_reviews.text: I use this with a v60 at the cabin, camp ground, airbnb, and hotel when we don't want to bring along our larger grinder. I even use when we're at home occasionally. It's very compact without sacrificing a decent grind. My only complaint is that the grind adjustment would be difficult to dial in if you need to change it often. It's not a big deal if you're using the same brewing method most of the time. I give it a few clicks in either direction depending on the roast, but if you don't use it for a while it's hard to remember where your baseline is at.
customer_reviews.author: B Thornton

customer_reviews.title: Great, simple, easy to use portable grinder
customer_reviews.text: Instructions were clear and helpful, after you get your coarseness dialed in, the convenience of this small manual burr grinder will allow you to brew your favorite cup of fresh ground beans for maximum freshness and flavor. Brought this grinder to the office and replaced the ground coffee with some whole bean from BRCC. The grinder is a little bit smaller than i anticipated, but it's capacity is perfect for a nice strong cup of pourover. If you're looking for a manual grinder to make larger amounts of coffee, i would steer away from this and look into investing in an electric burr grinder. Takes a lot of turns to grind a full load of beans.
customer_reviews.author: Jared S.

customer_reviews.title: Great Portable Coffee Grinder - Most Bang for Your Buck
customer_reviews.text: This is a great grinder for coffee lovers. I have been testing several different grind levels for my french press and have found that this grinder produces a high quality coarse grind. I wish it had an indicator on the side that told you which level of coarseness you were set on but it is easy to reset and count the clicks. I'd recommend it if you don't want to spend the money on an electric grinder.
customer_reviews.author: Paul

customer_reviews.title: Flawed designed, not centered conical burr
customer_reviews.text: Took some months to write this review as I was pretty new to home coffe brewing when I bought this. I did notice immediately that the conical burr was not properly aligned resulting in uneven grinding. This has been getting worse with use, and I am getting some big rocks with my medium grind that ends up floating in the french press. There is no chance you can make an expresso with this uneven grind.. I see now this product is 40 dollars! Crazy! Don't waste your money!!
customer_reviews.author: Guillermo D.

customer_reviews.title: Lasted about 2 weeks
customer_reviews.text: I followed all the tips included within the package and it worked great. After cleaning it one day, I went to use it again and the center rod slipped and jammed. I wasn't exactly aware because I wasn't applying a lot of force, just followed the instructions as usual. I realized because I checked on my test grind and found the consistency to be too fine. I noticed the slippage caused the plastic piece to be permanently ruined. Paid the money about two weeks ago, so I didn't want to trash the whole thing. I went to their website, and found a replacement that costed more to ship than the piece itself :).
customer_reviews.author: Brandon Hidalgo

customer_reviews.title: As advertised, high quality.
customer_reviews.text: This is well made product that functions as it should. The recommended grind settings in the instructions work perfectly. I really did notice a difference in the coffee from when I was using pre-ground. The only minor issue is that it's a bit time-consuming. Other reviewers had mentioned that coarse grinding enough beans for a single french press was no time at all, but it does take around 5 minutes for me. Wouldn't recommend using this for anything finer than that, unless you've got the time and the arm strength. Still, that's to be expected with a manual grinder, I suppose. The finished cup of coffee is worth it for me.
customer_reviews.author: Jason Gillis

customer_reviews.title: Easy for 1 cup— LOTS OF WORK for more.
customer_reviews.text: I would say that for the most-part, the grind is pretty even! There are times when it seems that (especially with the medium grinds) the grind is uneven, but i think the placebo effect makes it worth it hahah. Coffee can be an art if you invest time and a little more money into it. I just got a nice electric conical burr grinder because I am tired of grinding for 2 minutes in my tightly-packed morning when I could be doing something else. It’s fun for starters but I recommend investing in a nice electric grinder— this one just isn’t practical ESPECIALLY if you want to make coffee for more than one person.
customer_reviews.author: Samuel G

customer_reviews.title: Works as advertised and makes better-tasting coffee than my electric blade grinder
customer_reviews.text: I'm enjoying the product. So far it seems well-built and makes better-tasting coffee in my french press than my electric blade grinder did. I've seen complaints here about the time it takes to grind. Well, that's how burr grinders work. It only takes a few minutes to grind a full load in there and that's good for two large coffee cups of regular-strength coffee or one strong one. If you want a hands-free grind, or need more capacity there are electric burr grinders available or you can pre-cook the flavor out of your beans using a high-speed blade grinder like I used to. Your choice. :D
customer_reviews.author: Oceas

customer_reviews.title: Inconsistent and Inconvenient
customer_reviews.text: This coffee grinder does grind coffee so that's a plus. Unfortunately it's extremely inconsistent since the internal mechanisms wiggle side to side so much. Some chunks were coming out about the size of 1/3 of a bean by the time we gave up and decided to return the grinder and buy a different one. This also isn't a great grinder if you intend to have different size grinds regularly as switching back and forth is fairly difficult and finding the exact right setting again is a task in itself. They did have free return though, which was nice.
customer_reviews.author: Lola

customer_reviews.title: Only as a back up...
customer_reviews.text: I bought this little grinder as a back up for when I lose electricity during a storm etc. I think for that use it’ll be fine. But to use it every day I would not because of all the reasons that have been stated in many reviews. My main complaint is the fact that the top slips onto the bottom so while you’re grinding, you really do have to awkwardly hold both top and bottom at the same time to keep it from coming apart while you grind. I would think a simple solution to that would be to have the top screw onto the bottom. But in an emergency I think it will work fine.
customer_reviews.author: AmazonWoman

customer_reviews.title: Vast grinding settings
customer_reviews.text: The grinder has a nice metal design, a huge number of grinding settings for whatever you need all in a nice small package. Perfect for travel or camping. The only negative is that you have to get a feel for the grind setting because it is just by number of clicks, and over thirty clicks in total to cycle through. Other than that it is perfect. Edit: I attached my cordless drill to this (very easy) and this thing grinds really fast if you don't want to bother with manual labor. It offers a lot of grind settings and is now technically electric so an even better deal now.
customer_reviews.author: Clure

customer_reviews.title: Morning workout
customer_reviews.text: If you’re looking for a grinder which will have you manually grinding coffee in the early morning while you’re half asleep and wishing you’d have bought an automatic grinder then this is what you’re looking for. In the morning, after I get out of bed, beard and hair disheveled I looked forward to groggily walking to my kitchen and getting out my scale to weigh the amount of coffee I will be using with my hipster chemex brewer. As I manually crank away I feel regret that I did not splurge and get that automatic grinder to make this chore easier. However after having my coffee I feel a sense of accomplishment knowing that I made this coffee.
customer_reviews.author: NarwalBacons

customer_reviews.title: Efficient And Lots Of Fun
customer_reviews.text: As someone else has already pointed out, it can take a little experimentation to get the grind set to the right point, but it's fun testing it out to get exactly what you want. I've found exactly what I want, but I've also found some interesting variations that give a noticeable change in the flavor. It's small enough to pack while traveling and well constructed. I've especially enjoyed having it with me to test out a new bean I come across before buying a larger quantity. It has earned a permanent place on the kitchen counter, except for when it's in my suitcase.
customer_reviews.author: Mary A. MadsenTop Contributor: Cooking

customer_reviews.title: A Great Coffee Experience.
customer_reviews.text: While it does take a little more time and effort to use, the results are worth it. The grounds are consistent on a medium grind at 8-9 clicks, the more coarse the less consistent but that stands to reason. For 1/3 cup of medium grounds, fill the bean reservoir and grind away. It takes about 4 minutes to grind. The crank handle seats well and turning is not difficult. We bought this to go with the Bodum Pour Over Coffee Maker  using low-acid Tres Hermanos organic coffee  You will not be disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Sherry

customer_reviews.title: Perfect
customer_reviews.text: I wasn't sure about getting a grinder. There is always one wherever I buy coffee. Then I tried this one and I changed my perspective. It adds a few minutes to the morning routine but grinding coffee just before you add water improved the taste quite a bit. I like dark and robust coffee and this raised my game a bit. It is simple to load and just the right size for 24 grams of beans. Go to your happy place while your arms grind and then tap the grounds into your coffee maker. Add water and kick back with a cup. Nice!
customer_reviews.author: AJ

customer_reviews.title: Great Little Grinder
customer_reviews.text: I've been using this grinder everyday for the past two weeks, and I am SO pleased with it! I am the only coffee drinker in the house, so I brew one cup of coffee in a Keurig every morning. It was a delight to find an alternative to the very expensive k-cups. Now I grind my favorite beans fresh every morning in the time it takes for my Keurig to heat up the water. This grinder may be small, but it is mighty! Easy to fill, easy to use. One of the best gifts I gave myself this year!
customer_reviews.author: DowntownLady51

customer_reviews.title: Use a cordless drill for better results
customer_reviews.text: Wanted to have really good coffee, I was told you needed a ceramic Burr grinder and do it by hand. Well, I tried, gave me really fine grounds for my automatic drip, but it took me a half hour to get 2 tablespoons, seriously people, I'm not freaking Amish, I dont have the patience. So I took off the handle and attached my DeWalt cordless drill to the bit on top, it has variable speeds, so I could still go slow, just not hand grind slow. Now I make grinds in 5 minutes. Perfect....
customer_reviews.author: daniel sullivan

customer_reviews.title: Love it! Use it everyday!
customer_reviews.text: This is a very convenient tool for freshly ground coffee. The first one I received was defective (the bottom would fall off and I’d have to hold it on place while trying to ground) the company sent a replacement right away. Their customer service is excellent ( thank you Gwendolyn! ) The new one I received is perfect and has been working perfectly! I use it for my French press. I will also add I have arthritis and tendinitis in my wrists and I am able to use this grinder comfortably.
customer_reviews.author: KB

customer_reviews.title: Great for single cups
customer_reviews.text: I use this to make 1 serving of coffee (400 grams of water) every morning, I use 20 grams of beans and it takes me 2-3 minutes to grind it all at a fairly course setting for pour over coffee. I have not used any finer settings than pour over but I am very pleased with the course grind for pour over. I wrapped the top and bottom section with a strip of athletic tape to make it easier to grip while grinding.
customer_reviews.author: Donald Hollingsworth

customer_reviews.title: Easy To Use/ Great Grind
customer_reviews.text: This is a great little grinder for brewing 1-2 cups of coffee. It ground the beans very well as long as you use good quality beans. Cheap beans did not work well. The high quality beans I got directly from Kona, Hawaii made a fabulous cup of coffee. The only issue I have is due to the arthritis is my hands. I had to use a rubber gripper for opening lids on jars to get a good grip on the cylinder while grinding. Also, if you’re needing a grinder for large pots of coffee, this probably will not suit your needs. Since I’m the only coffee drinker in my home, it’s perfect for me.
customer_reviews.author: Charlotte Simer

customer_reviews.title: I returned it. But wait!
customer_reviews.text: Great product. Just not for me. The coffee resulting from the time spent grinding was delicious! However, I decided that I do not have the patience to grind that long or much for each cup of coffee. Plus I add sweetener and/or creamer anyway, so I decided to just buy the already ground version of the coffee. That being said, the grinder works great. It is easy to use, easy to clean, nice and compact, and seems sturdy. If I ever decide that I have the patience to grind beans, I'll buy this again. I would recommend this to my more patient friends.
customer_reviews.author: Frank Meffert

customer_reviews.title: Great for travel, not so for everyday kitchens
customer_reviews.text: I can see how this would be a great product for those that travel & coffee. I bought it for home and use it on a daily basis: it gets old, I wish I had bought an electrical one. Maybe if it had a gear system that provides more revolutions per turn? After using it, ground coffee sticks into the grooves and if you wash it, water condenses in between the metal and the plastic which could cause some problems if it’s stored without drying correctly. Not a bad product, just not for everyday kitchens IMO.
customer_reviews.author: Audinac

customer_reviews.title: A good grinder for the price
customer_reviews.text: This grinder is not extremely precise as the grinder can be slightly tilted but it gives you enough control to get very close to the grind you need, especially for the price. The coarseness is set with a turn screw, not with any fixed settings, so you have to experiment a little to find the right grind but it's not a big deal. The overall aesthetic is nice, the build quality seems good, and the act of hand-grinding for your cup is enjoyable. It's max capacity is about 32 grams which you can grind in about the same time it takes to heat up your water.
customer_reviews.author: Bill B

customer_reviews.title: Not for every day use, wears out quickly
customer_reviews.text: This product isn't made very well. The handle was always uncomfortable and hard to get off. It became striped after a while and can no longer grind. Also when i went to clean it one of the small rubber buffer rings disintegrated and was no longer useable. Now it's just a piece of metal to recycle. Before it broke it was relatively easy to use and good for traveling but it had a very short life span. I'd recommend buying a higher quality grinder unless you only use it once a year or something.
customer_reviews.author: araya carreiro

customer_reviews.title: Wind it up!!
customer_reviews.text: Just began my journey as a coffee connoisseur and thought I would go the “purist” route and get a manual grinder. NOT!!!!. Tried to hold out as long as I could, but just the act of “churning” the handle every morning got a bit old. (Not to mention if a second cup was desired!!!!). Portability is of course king with this grinder. The composite conical burr does it’s job. I just don’t know if I would be so anal as to need to grind my own beans while on vacation. Surely there’s a Starbucks somewhere near your next vacation spot! All in all, does it’s job, just a bit of a “GRIND”...(SORRY.....couldn’t help it :)
customer_reviews.author: Corey M. Peterson

customer_reviews.title: Cheap Inner Components
customer_reviews.text: Bought this grinder 2 months ago, and was initially very pleased as it did what I needed it to. After 2 months of consistent, everyday use the little plastic insert that connects the burr to the turning mechanism was so worn that it can't even grind at any setting (crank just spins without turning the burr). To further the frustration, the replacememt burr (which comes with that plastic insert) is out of stock on amazon and the javapresse website. The burr itself is still fine for my grinder but it sucks that I can't even purchase a replacement part (that likely costs <$2) individually. Will not be purchasing again.
customer_reviews.author: Tim Mielczarek

customer_reviews.title: Pretty, Well build and Slippery
customer_reviews.text: Does a great job of grinding for a french press. I don't mind the manual work; it makes the coffee that much more rewarding, but the stainless steel cylinder can be slippery. I have a pretty tough grip but I found the grinder slipping a little too often. A couple pieces of grip tape or talon grip tape take care of it no problem, but it would be awesome if there was a little bit of stippling around the grippy parts.
customer_reviews.author: Vincent Defrancesco

customer_reviews.title: Handy
customer_reviews.text: Bought it pre pandemic lockdown anticipating some future travel. Well that is not going to happen any time soon. It takes some experimentation to get the grind down, but I did expect that. Darn good quality and pretty each to clean and use otherwise.
customer_reviews.author: Jillie0808

customer_reviews.title: Great little ginder
customer_reviews.text: I'm very happy with my JavaPresse manual grinder. It's smaller than I expected, but that's a plus. It's easy to carry around and grind at the same time. I enjoy sitting by the fire and grinding the coffee while the water comes to a boil, or watching the light come up in the trees out the window. It takes a minute or two to grind enough for a single large pour-over cup-- no problem. I haven't had any problems, so haven't needed any customer service. But the company has reached out to offer help if needed. Seems like a good outfit. Highly recommended. And it makes for a wonderful cup of coffee!
customer_reviews.author: KLL

customer_reviews.title: Quality Product
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to use as a spice grinder. I like to buy whole spices and grind them as needed. The Javapresse grinder does a good job of this. The durability is unknown, but it is well built so that shouldn't be issue. I watched the video on the Javapresse website demonstrating how to use the grinder. The video was useful, but didn't answer the only question I had. How do you hold the shaft still while adjusting grind? I found that I had to attach the handle to hold the shaft in place while adjusting the grind. The demonstrator didn't appear to do this or anything, he just spun the black adjustment knob.
customer_reviews.author: momus

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for French Press
customer_reviews.text: Getting French Press Grind without a very expensive "power" grinder is great. I am an occasional user for a couple cups at a time. The JavaPresse is perfect for me. I get consistent grind with dial in perfection. My grandson recommended the JavaPresse and would never lead me astray. The unit is very easy to load with beans and hold while grinding. It has consistent solid feel and with a little shaking occasionally you know when the grind is finished. Highly recommended. I am in the occasional cleaning mode, but don't see its a big problem. Resetting the grind keeps me from "regular" cleaning.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer.

customer_reviews.title: Amazing Grinder for Even Coffee Grounds
customer_reviews.text: I've been into coffee for a long time and I've recently been looking into how to take my morning coffee to the next level and this grinder is it! It gives you even grounds which enhances the flavor of your coffee and cuts the bitterness. It's also small enough to travel with and offers a lot of customization in the size of your grounds with almost 20 levels of coarseness/fineness. I am VERY pleased with my purchase and have been using it every morning for the past three weeks. I love it!
customer_reviews.author: Julia

customer_reviews.title: Very Solid Coffee Grinder, grinds nice and fine
customer_reviews.text: Fresh ground coffee is always better than pre-grounded. However grinding myself one cup requires a ton of cranks, a lot more than I expected. it could take a good few minutes of spinning away at the handle to get just a little bit of beans ground. I don't mind doing it for myself, but if someone else comes over, it does almost feel like a chore. In other words I kind of wish I bought an electrical one. However I've heard the electric ones in this price range aren't very good.
customer_reviews.author: Gigi

customer_reviews.title: grinds, portable, gotta love it!
customer_reviews.text: I just love how portable and easy this thing is to use. A few improvements I'd like though: 1. A visual indicator of the grind's fine-ness (I tend to count the number of winds to be sure I'm as fine/coarse as I want my coffee to be. 2. padded cylindrical lids. while they aren't sharp, I don't see why a protective ring at the opening would ruin the experience. It'll feel a bit more expensive with that too.
customer_reviews.author: Roy

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Spice Grinder
customer_reviews.text: Confession -- it's never seen a coffee bean, but it has ground some spices quite efficiently and with the ease of clean-up, this makes me a very happy cook. If you do grind spices which are sticky or resinous you may want to purchase another grinder part to swap out. The grinder is somewhat porous so can retain the smell of ground substances. It did not do well with juniper berries and neither did any other grinder. I took a hammer to them outside on the patio. A nice little addition to the kitchen and NO Electricity required!!
customer_reviews.author: Jgd5055

customer_reviews.title: Works perfectly, once you figure out how to set the grind size.
customer_reviews.text: Taught myself how to make pour-over coffee and the JavaPresse grinder is a key ingredient of the entire process. Once you figure out the proper coffee grind size for your style of coffee, and you set the ceramic grinder, this unit works like a champ. There are online videos you can watch and JavaPresse provides you with all kinds of wonderful information on the proper brewing and selection of coffee. I love my JavaPresse and really enjoy the grinding and brewing process. It's fast, efficient and perfect for making a great cup of fresh coffee.
customer_reviews.author: Confidential

customer_reviews.title: Consistent grind for the price of a little squeak!
customer_reviews.text: Purchased: May 2019 Reviewed: November 2019 3*Ok, 4*Good, 5*Great Made in ??? Great grinder. A group of 3 to 5 of us use this almost every workday. Compared to our old bur grinder, this one is quieter with a more consistent grind. We all use different settings each day for press, pour over and making cold brew. Update: Used nearly daily by several people. Has a little squeak to it now; however, still a consistent grind. Constantly changing the grind setting for cold brew, press, etc.
customer_reviews.author: Lawrence

customer_reviews.title: Don't think about it - just buy it!
customer_reviews.text: It took a while before I could test this awesome little mechanical device out but I can tell you that it's a very High Quality coffee grinder and is a welcome addition to my backpack when I go camping and - if need be - for when we lose power due to a winter or summer storm in New England! Somehow, these folks tweaked this thing to make proper sized coffee grains resulting in the perfect brew. I'd buy it again and will likely buy another for a present to a family member! This is a solid piece of gear... I wouldn't hesitate to buy it now that I have bought it and used it!
customer_reviews.author: MH

customer_reviews.title: I love it, but it takes a goodly amount of time to grind
customer_reviews.text: Slowing down to appreciate the experience that is the first cup of coffee is a wonderful way to start the day. But sometimes, this grinder feels like a nag standing between me and my coffee. I would definitely recommend this grinder on the basis that it seems to be sturdy and makes uniform beanlettes. But just know that you are committing yourself to 5-10 minutes of time and attention.
customer_reviews.author: Karl Sokol

customer_reviews.title: Great little grinder
customer_reviews.text: The grinder showed up as described. It came with easy to follow instructions and a link to a great video site with everything you need to know about the grinder and all the how to's for grinding the perfect cup of coffee. It is made out of stainless steel and is very well built and sturdy and has a very small footprint. Worked great right out of the box. I would definitely recommend this grinder to anyone.
customer_reviews.author: Vman45

customer_reviews.title: Almost perfect
customer_reviews.text: I love using this grinder and have done so essentially every day for the past year- it has become part of my morning routine. However, the past 2 months it has become increasingly difficult to use; the handle and the bolt have both worn/stripped significantly with regular every day use, and now a year later, it is unusable. It’s a shame because I’m torn between ordering another one and looking for an alternative. It would be an easy 5 stars if it was built to last! However, if you’re only going to use it on occasion, or for traveling/camping, it should last you a long time! And it does make a great cup of coffee!
customer_reviews.author: Fish

customer_reviews.title: Nice tool for the coffee specialists
customer_reviews.text: Pretty good grinder. Solid construction and the burrs are nice. Grinds fairly consistent for a hand grinder and my coffee tastes pretty good. Only thing I'd mark of on is the ability for the bottom reservoir cup to drop off if you don't have a finger on it. I like to hold it up top, close to the crank arm for good leverage but that can leave the bottom cup dangling and risk falling off so i try to keep a pinky on the reservoir to prevent java-fallout.
customer_reviews.author: Fitz

customer_reviews.title: Nice idea, but it hurts my hand
customer_reviews.text: We have a small house and the walls are thin, so I was looking for something easy to store, clean and wouldn't make a lot of noise and wake my little boy up in the morning. This little grinder is very sleek looking and is all metal, which is great. The only problem is that it KILLS my hands to use it...and I am a piano player (Rachmaninoff, Chopin, Beethoven) so it's not like I have weak hands! I would use it more if there was something that would give it a little more grip.
customer_reviews.author: Khun Nali

customer_reviews.title: Good product but room for improvement
customer_reviews.text: Great grinder but I do have a few things that stuck out to me, not a total deal breaker but the handle is removable but there isn’t a way to attach it when not in use (if your not careful, it can get lost). It took several tries to adjust the grinder to get the consistency I wanted and it was kinda pain to clean after each use. Overall, it’s great for travel and portability, does a pretty good grinder once you figure it out.
customer_reviews.author: Jenn

customer_reviews.title: Worth the money, and the grind time!
customer_reviews.text: As I am getting more serious with my coffee, and it’s taste - it was recommended that I buy a grinder as opposed to buying pre-ground coffee. I’ve heard mixed reviews about automatic grinders so I went with the manual coffee grinder instead. There is something rewarding about grinding the beans yourself, perfectly measuring out the coarseness for your coffee, smelling the aroma along the way, and the gratification of the final product. The product has worked perfectly so far, and though it may take a little longer to grind the beans than expected, I am very happy I went with a manual grinder!
customer_reviews.author: Tully

customer_reviews.title: Top piece doesn’t fit well to bottom piece.
customer_reviews.text: This is our second coffee grinder from this company, both same model. The first one worked great for a long time but eventually it became difficult to remove the handle to fill with beans because the axel lost it exact shape. Our second one has never worked well because the whole bean reservoir does not fit well into the ground coffee reservoir because the fit is so loose it is hard to grind and hold the two pieces together. To be fair, I have not attempted to ask the company for help. Otherwise, a very good product.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works well, takes many turns to grind enough coffee
customer_reviews.text: I travel in my van converted to an RV all the time and like this grinder a lot. It's small and easy to use. My only complaint is that it takes many turns to grind enough for a couple of cups of coffee. I have started using my cordless drill at slow speed attached to the grinder in place of the handle provided for hand turning. It still takes quite a while, maybe a minute, to grind my beans to a medium coarse grind. Still, I think it is a very good product.
customer_reviews.author: Quintessential

customer_reviews.title: Use a drill to spin it clockwise. I just save you a ton of time...
customer_reviews.text: Best advice is to use a cordless drill instead of the handle. Have been watching my wife use this thing and spin it clockwise by hand for a month or two. She gave it to me a couple of times to do for a while. We do Chia and flax seed with it. I looked at it the other day and said I have an idea. Used my drill. Turned a 30 min job in to a 30 second job. Works flawlessly.
customer_reviews.author: Krystle Walsh

customer_reviews.title: I'm completely satisfied with this purchase
customer_reviews.text: I'm completely satisfied with this purchase. I've only used the grinder a few times at this point, but it performs exactly as advertised. I'm happy that I bought this all-aluminum product as opposed the the competitors with glass or plastic receptacles, and I like its slender design for storage efficiency. It definitely yields a more consistent grind than the blade grinder I was using. Whether this leads to a better cup of coffee I can't say since my palate isn't quite that refined. But it requires little enough effort to get the benefits that the coffeeverse believes are there that I'll continue to use it and assume I'm getting them. Customer service appears to be first-rate.
customer_reviews.author: chuck

customer_reviews.title: Great device at this price point
customer_reviews.text: I have a burr grinding coffee maker and looking for something to make a single cup in an AeroPress as well as travel/hike etc. This fits that bill perfectly. The price is right, it's easy to use and clean and looks good. If there was one thing I'd wish it had is a way to store the handle, but that's not a deal killer. I'd recommend this for anyone that is grinding beans for a single cup a couple of times a week. If you're doing large quantities, this isn't the device for you as it does about one cup's worth at a time.
customer_reviews.author: Bull

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use and a great grind
customer_reviews.text: This is a great grinder for your small batch coffee or for taking with you on the road. To set the grind, you have to start at "0" then work back to get it to the grind texture you want. I just set it in the middle, ground a little bit and checked then adjusted from there. Pretty simple. I would definitely recommend this. It's about the size of a home version of a pepper mill. Handle comes off at the top and is easily broken down for storage.
customer_reviews.author: LeAnne K

customer_reviews.title: Not well made
customer_reviews.text: The handle has a hexagonal cutout that slips over the top of the grinding mechanism. The cutout in my handle was too loose so the grinder wouldn't work. I was going to ask for a new handle but then I saw how the mating surface was machined on the grinder shaft and realized they were also poorly formed. The stainless section is made very well but the the handle is a very weak design.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Grinds without the heat of an electric grinder
customer_reviews.text: I needed a grinder that could grind specifically for my Moka coffee pot. This coffee grinder is slim and trim, easy to put together, and easy to use (read the instructions first, engineers and stubborn people like me!). You don't need to take the whole thing apart to clean it (I did this) but it's easy enough to put back together if you follow the video online. Grinds well. Good coffee!
customer_reviews.author: Pamela Norton

customer_reviews.title: Definitely labor intensive, but results seem great so far
customer_reviews.text: If you just want a quick cup of coffee, I don't think a manual coffee grinder is for you. It's a little 3-4 minute workout before each day's coffee. So, it's aimed at people who value quality over convenience. But, the aroma is great, unit is adjustable to get different sized grounds. Simple enough construction, easy to wash, and doesn't take up nearly as much space as an electric model on your countertop. Very happy with the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: Nathan S.

customer_reviews.title: Great little grinder
customer_reviews.text: I was a bit skeptical about the amount of time it would take to grind the amount of beans needed for my cup of coffee. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it takes less than two minutes. Finding the right grind was also easy to achieve. I now look forward to preparing my cup of coffee because of this little grinder. It certainly beats my old electric one, for quality of grind and finished coffee, and it’s much more pleasant to use!
customer_reviews.author: Lacey Gonzales

customer_reviews.title: The ceramic burr wobbles and the handle broke
customer_reviews.text: As stated in the title the ceramic burr wobbles leading to an inconsistent grind and I have to keep checking the setting I put it in because it keep tightening itself furthering the inconsistency of the grind plus the handle didn't even last a day.
customer_reviews.author: Ryan Demientieff

customer_reviews.title: Not for me
customer_reviews.text: I bought this because of all the good reviews. I just dont think it is practical for me. I spend a long time grinding and it deters me from making coffee. This will be great for camping trips and such but I think I need an electric burr grinder to satify my coffee making needs.
customer_reviews.author: Bret

customer_reviews.title: A piece of sh!t
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this twice, both times I was SUPER careful with it, and it broke within a month. Nothing is more frustrating than rushing to work, looking forward to your morning coffee and have it not work. How did it get this many stars is a mystery to me. I thought at least for the hefty price it would be reliable but no..
customer_reviews.author: M.

customer_reviews.title: No French Connection
customer_reviews.text: Bought this manual grinder to make French press coffee. After some experimentation, got a nice coarse grind, per the recipe. As others have noted, it takes time to grind even a quarter cup of beans. Perhaps we have been spoiled by electric blade grinders? Followed the French press instructions to the letter. They yielded a cup of weak, tepid, tasteless coffee. So, back to the single cup fine grind coffee approach, in my gold filter. Will try this grinder for the fine grind, and compare it to the blade grinder. Since they both are likely to yield the same product, will probably choose twenty-five seconds over several minutes of manual cranking. Product simple and as advertised. Portable too.
customer_reviews.author: Dirk D.

product_meta.title: JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder with Adjustable Setting - Conical Burr Mill & Brushed Stainless Steel Whole Bean Burr Coffee Grinder for Aeropress, Drip Coffee, Espresso, French Press, Turkish Brew
